entry.title: Armenian government may sell off stake in telecoms operator Viva: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS

media:group.media:title: Armenian government may sell off stake in telecoms operator Viva: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS
media:group.media:description:
üìç A senior Central Bank official said a technical failure was behind recent outages of Armenia‚Äôs national payment network. There is no evidence of a cyberattack, and no personal information has leaked as a result of the outages, Armen Nurbekyan added. üìç The Central Bank held interest rates steady at 6.75%, citing heightened levels of uncertainty around U.S. trade policy and elevated global geopolitical tensions. üìç The government took a step toward selling its minority stake in Viva Armenia, one of the country‚Äôs main telecommunications operators, to the company‚Äôs majority owners. It expects $50 million in compensation for handing over its 20% stake to Fedilco Group.

entry.title: Creating vibrant border communities for displaced Artsakhis

media:group.media:title: Creating vibrant border communities for displaced Artsakhis
media:group.media:description:
Creating vibrant and sustainable communities in Armenia‚Äôs border regions is the Paros Foundation‚Äôs mission. Executive Director Peter Abajian shares success stories to demonstrate how Paros programs resettle families exiled from Artsakh into border towns benefit both the municipalities and the new residents. He also talks about challenges within the context of the huge need to integrate tens of thousands of people.
0:00- Introduction 1:20- Responding to Artsakh tragedies 3:20- Selecting resettlement locations 4:48- Economic opportunities on the border 6:12- Choosing the beneficiaries 7:53- Challenges faced in resettlement 9:34- Positive effects of resettlement on children 11:33- Navigating diaspora burnout

entry.title: Lost Souls: Soviet Displaced Persons and the Birth of the Cold War - Sheila Fitzpatrick

media:group.media:title: Lost Souls: Soviet Displaced Persons and the Birth of the Cold War - Sheila Fitzpatrick
media:group.media:description:
Sheila Fitzpatrick, prominent Australian historian and widely regarded as one of the leading scholars of Soviet and modern Russian history, delivers a lecture titled "Lost Souls" at the 2025 Monterey Summer Symposium on Russia. The presentation took place on July 1, 2025, in Yerevan, as part of the symposium organized by the Monterey Initiative in Russian Studies at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey. The symposium ran from June 25 to July 13, 2025, across three regional capitals: Batumi, Yerevan, and Tbilisi.
Key Points from the Lecture:
Fitzpatrick examines one of the most successful refugee resettlement programs in history, involving half a million Soviet displaced persons (DPs) in post-WWII Germany who refused repatriation to the USSR. She reveals how these refugees demonstrated remarkable agency within restrictive circumstances, constantly strategizing and repositioning themselves despite appearing as "pawns of fate." The DPs could choose their identities on registration cards, decide when not to accept resettlement offers to undesirable countries, and even reinvent their professional backgrounds‚Äîas famously occurred when a shipload of supposed manual laborers transformed into professors and opera singers during their voyage to Australia. The historian traces the geopolitical transformation of the DP problem from a humanitarian crisis to a Cold War asset. Initially defined as "victims of war and fascism" under UNRRA, the displaced persons were successfully rebranded as "victims of communism" when the American-funded International Refugee Organization (IRO) took over in 1947. This narrative shift proved crucial for securing US Congressional funding, as the DPs became "poster children for the choice of freedom and democracy over totalitarianism" during the early Cold War period. Fitzpatrick's analysis reveals the racial and national hierarchies that determined resettlement success, with recipient countries showing clear preferences for Baltic peoples over Slavs, and implementing various exclusionary practices against non-Europeans. She concludes by contrasting this successful resolution with the contemporaneous Palestinian refugee crisis‚Äîtwo problems of similar scale, but only one solved due to the DPs' ability to present themselves as white, European, and anti-communist. The lecture demonstrates how changing the narrative around refugees can determine their fate, though Fitzpatrick notes this "recipe" for solving refugee crises isn't universally applicable.

entry.title: Glendale to Gosh: Diasporans navigating village life in Armenia

media:group.media:title: Glendale to Gosh: Diasporans navigating village life in Armenia
media:group.media:description:
Asbed and Aida Bogharian moved from Los Angeles to Gosh and launched initiatives to inspire future generations. They explain to CivilNet how they‚Äôve navigated cultural differences between diasporans and locals in the village and what they‚Äôve learned along the way.

media:group.media:description:
–í –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–≤—å—é CivilNet –ø—Ä–æ—Ñ–µ—Å—Å–æ—Ä —Å–æ—Ü–∏–æ–ª–æ–≥–∏–∏ –ù—å—é-–ô–æ—Ä–∫—Å–∫–æ–≥–æ —É–Ω–∏–≤–µ—Ä—Å–∏—Ç–µ—Ç–∞ –≤ –ê–±—É-–î–∞–±–∏ –ì–µ–æ—Ä–≥–∏–π –î–µ—Ä–ª—É–≥—å—è–Ω —Å—Ä–∞–≤–Ω–∏–≤–∞–µ—Ç –Ω—ã–Ω–µ—à–Ω–∏–µ –∞—Ä–º—è–Ω–æ-–∞–∑–µ—Ä–±–∞–π–¥–∂–∞–Ω—Å–∫–∏–µ –ø–µ—Ä–µ–≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä—ã –≤ –í–∞—à–∏–Ω–≥—Ç–æ–Ω–µ —Å ‚Äú–ë—Ä–µ—Å—Ç—Å–∫–∏–º –º–∏—Ä–æ–º‚Äù 1918 –≥–æ–¥–∞, —Ä–∞—Å–∫—Ä—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç –ø–æ–¥–æ–ø–ª–µ–∫—É –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–∞ –¢—Ä–∞–º–ø–∞ –∫ –º–∞—Ä—à—Ä—É—Ç—É —á–µ—Ä–µ–∑ –°—é–Ω–∏–∫, –æ–±—ä—è—Å–Ω—è–µ—Ç, –ø–æ—á–µ–º—É —É –ê–∑–µ—Ä–±–∞–π–¥–∂–∞–Ω–∞ –Ω–µ—Ç –≤–æ–∑–º–æ–∂–Ω–æ—Å—Ç–∏ —Ä–µ–∞–ª–∏–∑–æ–≤–∞—Ç—å —Å–∏–ª–æ–≤–æ–π —Å—Ü–µ–Ω–∞—Ä–∏–π –∏ –ø—Ä–µ–¥—É–ø—Ä–µ–∂–¥–∞–µ—Ç: –≤—Å—ë, —á—Ç–æ –ø–æ–¥–ø–∏—Å—ã–≤–∞–µ—Ç—Å—è ‚Äî –ø—Ä–æ—Å—Ç–æ –±—É–º–∞–≥–∏.
–ü–æ—á–µ–º—É –¢—Ä–∞–º–ø –º–æ–∂–µ—Ç —Å—ã–≥—Ä–∞—Ç—å —Å–≤–æ—é "–≤–æ—Å—Ç–æ—á–Ω—É—é —Å–¥–µ–ª–∫—É", —á—Ç–æ —Å—Ç–æ–∏—Ç –∑–∞ –∏–Ω–≤–µ—Å—Ç–∏—Ü–∏—è–º–∏ –∞–º–µ—Ä–∏–∫–∞–Ω—Å–∫–æ–π ExxonMobil, –∏ –∫–∞–∫ –∫–æ–Ω—Ñ–ª–∏–∫—Ç —Ü–µ—Ä–∫–≤–∏ –∏ –≥–æ—Å—É–¥–∞—Ä—Å—Ç–≤–∞ –≤ –ê—Ä–º–µ–Ω–∏–∏ –º–æ–∂–µ—Ç –æ–±–µ—Ä–Ω—É—Ç—å—Å—è —à–∞–≥–æ–º –∫ –µ–≤—Ä–æ–ø–µ–π—Å–∫–æ–π –º–æ–¥–µ–ª–∏ –¥–µ–º–æ–∫—Ä–∞—Ç–∏–∏ ‚Äî –≤ –º–∞—Å—à—Ç–∞–±–Ω–æ–º –∞–Ω–∞–ª–∏–∑–µ –ø—Ä–æ—Ñ–µ—Å—Å–æ—Ä–∞ –î–µ—Ä–ª—É–≥—å—è–Ω–∞.

entry.title: Pashinyan, Aliyev to endorse ‚ÄòTrump route‚Äô through southern Armenia

media:group.media:title: Pashinyan, Aliyev to endorse ‚ÄòTrump route‚Äô through southern Armenia
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan and Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev are expected to sign a joint letter withdrawing their countries from the Minsk Group at the White House tomorrow. They have also reportedly agreed in a solution for the transit route in Syunik, dubbed ‚ÄòTrump Route for International Peace‚Äô üìç The Armenian National Committee of America (ANCA) warned that the expected joint statement or memorandum could legitimize Azerbaijan‚Äôs ‚Äúgenocidal actions‚Äù and derail prospects for a just peace in the region. üìç Displaced Karabakh Armenians are facing growing uncertainty after a sharp reduction in state rent subsidies that took effect on June 1, limiting support to only the most vulnerable groups.

media:group.media:title: Washington Meeting: Peace or Theater?
media:group.media:description:
In this episode of Insights, host Eric Hacopian previews the trilateral meeting with Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan, U.S. President Donald Trump, and Azerbaijan‚Äôs President Ilham Aliyev, explaining why they‚Äôll likely ‚Äúinitial‚Äù a peace deal without signing it. Havipian also discusses how a U.S. controlled Syunik corridor hands Aliyev access with zero concessions, and why dropping genocide and war-crime cases against Baku would mark a moral and strategic surrender.
